tn.text: This phrase introduces the beginning of another event in the storyline. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_newevent]])
far from where most people live

This means that she was unfaithful in their relationship and that she began to sleep with other men. This can be stated explicitly if necessary. AT: "began to sleep with other men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: His servant was with him, and a pair of donkeys
tn.text: "He took with him his servant and two donkeys"

tn.ref: His father-in-law, the girl's father, persuaded
tn.text: in-law, the girl's father, persuaded** - "His father-in-law, that is, the girl's father, persuaded" or "The girl's father persuaded"
"spoke to him so he decided to stay"
the Levite prepared

tn.ref: Strengthen yourself with a bit of bread
tn.text: Here "bread" refers to "food." AT: "Eat some food so you will be strong enough to travel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Please be willing to spend the night
tn.text: "Please stay another night" (UDB)

tn.ref: Strengthen yourself, and wait until the afternoon
tn.text: The father-in-law is suggesting that he strengthen himself by eating. He is also asking him to wait until the afternoon to leave. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Eat some food so you will be strong enough to travel, and wait until afternoon to leave" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: now the day is advancing toward evening
tn.text: "the day is almost over" or "it is almost evening"
"which was later called Jerusalem"

tn.ref: He had a pair of saddled donkeys
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "He put saddles on his two donkeys" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an idiom used to make a suggestion. AT: "I suggest that we" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means to take a break from their journey and stop somewhere along the route. AT: "stop at" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means to take a break from their journey and stop at a place along the route. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:19:10|19:11]]. AT: "stop at" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom used to make a suggestion. AT: "I suggest that we" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means to take a break from their journey and stop at a place along the route. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:19:10|19:11]]. AT: "stopped" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
the marketplace where people gathered during the day
This phrase means for someone to invite them to spend the night in their home. AT: "invited them to stay in their house for that night" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
A Benjamite was a descendant of Benjamin. Translate the name of these people the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:03:15|3:15]].
Here the man looked up and paid attention to what was around him. AT: "He looked up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
the marketplace where people gathered during the day. Translate this the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:19:14|19:14]].

tn.ref: who will take me into his house
tn.text: This phrase refers to someone inviting other people into his house to spend the night there. AT: "who has invited me to stay in his house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the Levite says "me," but he is actually referring to himself along with his servant and his concubine. AT: "will take us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: and there is bread and wine
tn.text: Change to active voice. AT: "and we have plenty of bread and wine" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: me and your female servant here, and for this young man with your servants
tn.text: The Levite speaks of himself and the others as servants and in the third person to show respect. AT: "me, my concubine, and my servant"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
This can be written as a positive statement. AT: "We have everything we need" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
"Do not." The word "only" is used here to emphasize what he did not want the Levite to do.
This refers to the city square. Translate this the same as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jdg:19:16|19:17]].

tn.ref: brought the Levite into his house
tn.text: This means that he invited the Levite to spend the night in his house. Also, by inviting the Levite he was inviting the man's concubine and servant as well. AT: "invited the Levite and his servants to stay in his house" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: they were making their hearts glad
tn.text: The phrase "making their hearts glad" is an idiom that means to have a good time with someone else. AT: "they were have a good time together" (UDB) or "they were enjoying themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: some men of ... surrounded the house
tn.text: Some men stood on all sides of the house.
This word is used to get the peoples' attention. AT: "Listen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the men would not listen to him
tn.text: Here the author speaks of "agreeing" as if it were "listening." AT: "the men would not accept his offer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
there could be confusion as to the identity of the man. AT: "the Levite seized his concubine"
"when the sun was coming up" or "at first light" This refers to when the sun begins to rise.
This refers to morning when it is bright outside. AT: "the sun was fully risen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The woman did not answer because she was dead. This can be stated clearly. AT: "But she did not answer because she was dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

"section by section"  The author uses this graphic description of how the Levite cut up her body into specific pieces to emphasize what he did. "Limbs" refers to a person's arms and legs. If there is not a similar phrase in your language, this description may be left out of the translation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"12 pieces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: sent the pieces everywhere throughout Israel
tn.text: This means that he sent sent the different pieces to twelve different areas of Israel. AT: "sent each piece to a different place throughout Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
